summary: Finn Jones, a good man and talented actor when iron fist season 1 got bad reviews:
body:
Finn Jones, a good man and talented actor when iron fist season 1 got bad reviews:

“It was made for the fans, not the critics.”

You people:”He’s jUsT uSiNg tHAt aS An eXcuSe!!!.!.!.”

Brie Larson, the white feminist archetype, when people give negative reviews of a wrinkle in time/captain Marvel: “I don’t want to hear what a white man has to say about captain marvel/ wrinkle in time. It wasn’t made for them”

Your dumbasses: “yuSSS qUEen sLay!”

summary: Ok so I finally saw captain marvel the other day *mild spoilers if you haven’t seen it yet*
body:
Ok so I finally saw captain marvel the other day *mild spoilers if you haven’t seen it yet*

And you know what I was most shook about the whole movie not he fact that she had kick ass spacesuit or cute kitty or the whole skrull situation no ya boi was most shook when Brie Larson was back in Maria rambos house tryin to explain how she was missing all those years and she didn’t believe her so she put her hand on the kettle and boiled some straight fucking water into tea juice. Like hello I need that. Do you have any idea how bad I am at letting my tea go cold omfg

summary: Why is it that if someone does not like Captain Marvel or Brie Larson they are automatically a bitter, whiny, sexist, white boy?...
body: Why is it that if someone does not like Captain Marvel or Brie Larson they are automatically a bitter, whiny, sexist, white boy? But Wonder Woman and Gal Gadot are generally well received? Could it be that maybe Captain Marvel just wasn’t as good a movie and Brie Larson isn’t as likeable a person and have nothing to do with sex, race, or feminism?

reblog.comment: Why is it that if someone does not like Captain Marvel or Brie Larson they are automatically a bitter, whiny, sexist, white boy? But Wonder Woman and Gal Gadot are generally well received? Could it be that maybe Captain Marvel just wasn’t as good a movie and Brie Larson isn’t as likeable a person and have nothing to do with sex, race, or feminism?

trail.content_raw: Why is it that if someone does not like Captain Marvel or Brie Larson they are automatically a bitter, whiny, sexist, white boy? But Wonder Woman and Gal Gadot are generally well received? Could it be that maybe Captain Marvel just wasn’t as good a movie and Brie Larson isn’t as likeable a person and have nothing to do with sex, race, or feminism?
trail.content: Why is it that if someone does not like Captain Marvel or Brie Larson they are automatically a bitter, whiny, sexist, white boy? But Wonder Woman and Gal Gadot are generally well received? Could it be that maybe Captain Marvel just wasn’t as good a movie and Brie Larson isn’t as likeable a person and have nothing to do with sex, race, or feminism?

summary: I get that people want her to be gay and I definitely see that some people might read some of her mannerisms as giving up a gay...
question: I get that people want her to be gay and I definitely see that some people might read some of her mannerisms as giving up a gay vibe if that makes sense, like the way she sits and holds herself. BUT most of the "proof" is just projecting onto her bc we as gay girls long for more irl representation and shes just so supportive that it's easy to go there for her fans... this is in no way excusing the sharing of pics or people calling her gay on sm, just an observation
answer: ok YES YES YES YES DUDE and maybe brie likes getting us lesbians all riled up and MAYBE SHE SITS LIKE THAT BC IT’S COMFORTABLE BC LET’S BE HONEST IT IS and ok A LESBIAN CAN DREAM like good god almighty i know i fucking can, but i keep that strictly on tumblr and to myself, ( and god if brie has a tumblr and she sees this i’m sorry ) but we have to support her in EVERYTHING she does and NOT DEMAND she kisses girls onscreen or INSIST THAT SHE IS GAY like no bro we’re here to love and adore AND RESPECT HER !! she’s a cute lil cupcake and we MUST PROTECT !!

blog.name: geekherring
blog.title: Geek Herring
blog.description: A critical geek culture podcast for geeks everywhere focussed on female representation throughout geekdom.

summary: Episode 27: Geeking Out About Unicorn Store: Embrace Your Weird - geekherring.com
title: Episode 27: Geeking Out About Unicorn Store: Embrace Your Weird - geekherring.com
description:
Unicorn Store is Brie Larson’s directorial debut! It’s a bright, colourful, and totally extra coming of age film tackling some pretty tough issues. Learning to love yourself and those around you for who they are, even if you come with extra glitter and rainbows, and embracing your weird ass self, even when it feels like the whole world’s against you.

We both loved this film (some a bit more than others) and think that it brings up elements of life that everyone needs to think about. While the extraness might appeal to most of Gen Z and lots of Gen X (otherwise known as the Millennials), the lessons it teaches are so widely applicable.

If you’ve ever felt like you don’t belong, or you feel like your parents just don’t get you, or maybe the whole world doesn’t get you – this is a film for you. It’s heartwarming, endearing, and full of colour, mystery, and magic!

Hosts Monika and Amanda don’t see completely eye-to-eye about this film, and some pretty in-depth debate happens after a spoiler warning. Did Amanda manage to change Monika’s mind??

You’ll have to listen to find out!

Check out Unicorn Store on IMDB and watch it on Netflix for yourself!

If you’ve enjoyed this episode, please check out some of our others!

  • Geeking Out About Captain Marvel: Higher, Further, Faster, Feminist
  • Geek Girl Reviews: The Fangirl’s Guide to the Galaxy by Sam Maggs
  • Geek Girl Community: Support, Sisterhood, and Friendship

Love Geek Herring, please hop over to iTunes and leave us a review!

Geek out with Geek Herring Online / Facebook / Instagram / Twitter / Patreon!

Geekily yours,
Amanda & Monika
